sections.subHeader: I am a skilled and experienced engineer
sections.text: I am a forward-thinking, goal-oriented software engineer with DevOps experience, a reputation for writing well-tested, well-documented, reliable, and clean code and infrastructure. I am passionate about and automating things and designing for scalability. I'm fluent in Typescript and Python and experienced with C# and C++, and I pick up new programming languages easily. I am a team player focused on building robust, scalable systems, completing project objectives within their deadlines, and writing detailed documentation for others. I take pride in my work, and believe that the results that I produce should be my strongest advocate.

In all of my endeavors, I am constantly searching to expand my knowledge and abilities. At JMU, I found myself interested in everything STEM, so I took on two intense programs to graduate with degrees in Chemistry and Engineering as well as a minor in Mathematics. Outside of my work and formal education, you can find me reading, learning a new language, or crafting a new project. I am an avid reader, especially of history and sci-fi and I have a deep interest in linguistics and language as well. Currently, I'm proficient in Spanish, currently learning German, and I've dabbled in Swedish, Italian, and Norwegian. As for my craftsmanship, I built several of the furniture pieces which currently furnish my apartment. I also enjoy machining, 3D printing, and welding.

Diversity in thought is one of an organization's greatest strengths. The more diverse a group is, the more unique ideas and perspectives are present in the amalgam, resulting in a more thorough, better thought-out, and more robust final product. I bring with me the unique experience of five years of chemistry education as well as four years of education in multidisciplinary engineering. I am well-versed in physics, thermodynamics, chemistry, engineering, mathematics, history, music, and programming, and I love to apply my knowledge to new problems.

When I look at code I wrote years ago, I will often feel a slight sense of embarrassment: _"Did I really write that?"_ But when I look at my old code and I don't think that, I have a worse feeling: _"Am I not improving?"_ It is good to be embarrassed by the quality of your old code because that indicates that your standards and ability now are greater than when the code was written. Sometimes I laugh at the quality of my older projects on GitHub, but I leave them as a reminder of how far I've come, and how much further I will go.

sections.subHeader: I don't miss the forest for the trees
sections.text: In my engineering classes, I learned how to synthesize vague and abstract project ideas into concrete, quantifiable, and specific requirements, wants, nice-to-haves, etc, and then to convert those into action items. This is a key part of being a leader in a software development team, and it is one of my favorite parts of my job. I love taking a project from the concept phase to the production phase. It is crucial to keep track of the larger puzzle that a given project fits into in all parts of the project lifecycle, and this is something that I am very good at.

sections.subHeader: I pay a lot of attention to the trees
sections.text: I have always been a detail-oriented thinker, and I take great pride in the quality of my work. This is true in all areas; I love to take my time perfecting a piece of furniture, or re-writing a song. I also love the feeling of satisfaction that I get from writing clean code, but I realize that sometimes the qualities that we think of as "clean code" can be at odds with performance or cost optimization, and that sometimes, I have to set aside my craftsman-orientation towards coding in favor of a bigger-picture perspective.

points.blurb: When my technical team lead quit in August 2021, I took on many of the role's responsibilities, and as those responsibilities increased, I proved more than capable of handling them.
items: Architected and spearheaded development of several support services and applications which were integral to the timely rollout of CoStar Sync, which is described in [this](https://aws.amazon.com/solutions/case-studies/costar-opensearch-case-study/) AWS case study
Onboarded and mentored multiple newly-hired engineers
Wrote in-depth wiki articles for internal users of the applications that my team is responsible for

points.blurb: As a software engineer, I proved my ability to own multiple projects and play a key role in pushing their development forward.
items: Architected and spearheaded development of session management system supplementary to OAUTH-2 that allows detection and prevention of software license abuse for 105 million monthly unique visitors, as well as other session management features

Designed and built CoStar’s Application Vending Machine, which streamlines project development by allowing developers to write parameterized yeoman-based project templates which describe file structure, branch policies, and Azure DevOps YAML templates. These templates can then be used to create new projects, and then create automated pull requests to the managed projects when the template is updated.
Designed and implemented efficient and scalable distributed cloud-based software systems
Assumed many of the responsibilities of team lead for over a year due to hiring difficulties and led a team of 3 through the completion of multiple projects from start to finish during this time
Synthesized vague and sometimes contradictory project requests into coherent requirements and stories
Migrated multiple projects from single-region AWS architecture to multi-region architecture
Was primary point-of-contact and knowledge source for multiple projects
Responsible for developing and maintaining CoStar’s PDF/Excel report generation service, which is a high-value, customer-facing product

points.blurb: After less than a year at the company, I was promoted from Associate Software Engineer to Software Engineer.
items: Built spikes as proof-of-concept and transformed them into fully featured services
Used infrastructure-as-code tools to manage releases and deployments
Designed and implemented CI/CD pipelines in Azure DevOps for validating builds, running unit and integration tests, and deploying development, test, and production environments
Designed and implemented monorepo-based version management system to automatically publish individual sub-packages for shared code to company NPM repository based on dependency tree changes
Coordinated within and across engineering teams and management to gather and refine requirements, improve user experience, and decrease operational costs
Wrote CLI scripts to automate pull request creation, validation, and completion
Wrote applications in Typescript and C#, and wrote DevOps scripts in bash and Python

points.blurb: From April 2020 – September 2020, I worked full-time. Since then, I've been on retainer to maintain and occasionally add features to the projects I completed in 2020.
items: Automated manual data analysis processes to save tens of person-hours of work per week
Set up, managed, and used CI/CD tools such as GitLab to use on on-premises server for git repository and automatic deployments of web applications to docker swarm
Later, I migrated the on-prem infrastructure I set up into Azure Cloud and integrated with Office365
Developed automotive and home insurance comparative rating system web application for internal use
Developed internal web application for tracking agent commissions across multiple agency locations
Developed automated processes for tracking customer retention, allowing agencies to significantly increase retention

points.blurb: I learned many valuable skills in the lab of Dr. Paul Raston.
items: Engineered and fabricated custom components for a helium nanodroplet isolation spectrometer
Designed, built, and coded (in C++) a microcontroller-based failsafe system for delicate scientific instruments
Automated laboratory procedures and data collection
Wrote open-source Python code for subtracting infrared spectra
Designed and implemented infrastructure for remotely controlling laboratory processes via the internet
Co-authored four peer-reviewed scientific publications, two of which I was the first author
Presented research findings at two international conferences, one national conference, and two regional conferences
Trained newer research assistants

points.blurb: I was hired as an intern to audit boxes of equipment picked by warehouse employees, but I automated ~80% of my job by developing a Python application to store, analyze, and report on warehouse data.
items: Designed and implemented application with GUI for tracking warehouse employee pick accuracy, analyzing daily and historical data, automatically generating detailed PDF reports, and distributing reports via email
Wrote detailed documentation tailored towards non-technical end-users of the application
Provided managers with new employee performance and item supply information gleaned by the application I developed, resulting in a significant increase in accuracy and performance
Minor in Mathematics
Wrote a websocket-based multiplayer game in NodeJS/React which was inspired by a Ray Dalio quote regarding monopoly as a simulation of the economy
This version of Monopoly allows players to make loans to each other with dynamic interest rates
Implemented a decision-making algorithm for "AI" players, which results in realistic, if sometimes comical, behavior (I'm still tweaking the algorithm)
Implemented a modular multiplayer system, which allows any number of human or AI players
Visualizes in-game economic data in real time, which reveals interesting boom/bust phenomena
Once I get the game into a more complete state, I plan to host it somewhere
GitHub repo [here](https://github.com/isaac-j-miller/monopoly)
Wrote a program which traverses a Typescript AST to generate C# data classes
GitHub repo [here](https://github.com/isaac-j-miller/ts-csharp-converter)
Designed and developed a lightweight, miniature CI server for self-hosted projects using Node.JS and Express
The purpose of this project is to make it easy to automate deployment of code to Raspberry Pi servers which do not have a public IP
I plan to re-implement in Python to make installation easier for Raspberry Pi hobbyists
GitHub repo [here](https://github.com/isaac-j-miller/lite-ci)
Designed, built, and coded a smart mirror using a Raspberry Pi
Recently re-worked the project to use my lite-ci package to incorporate CI/CD pipelines to keep the raspberry pi up-to-date without SSH-ing into it every time I push to main
GitHub repo [here](https://github.com/isaac-j-miller/mirror-v2)
Designed and implemented an open-source simulation of a helium nanodroplet isolation spectrometer for teaching purposes
Re-worked project to utilize distributed architecture, migrating from an ECS-based app to S3/API Gateway/Lambda
Reduced cloud hosting costs from approximately $15 per month to approximately $0.50 per month (__97% cost savings!__)
GitHub repo [here](https://github.com/isaac-j-miller/virtual-hendi)
Hosted [here](https://virtual-hendi.isaac-j-miller.com)
Developed a 2D arcade-style game using C++
Built polymorphic collision detection functions for collisions between different types of objects (i.e. lines, points, polygons)
Developed realistic physics system, which accidentally resulted in an accurate simulation of gravity and orbit (in 2 dimensions)
GitHub repo [here](https://github.com/isaac-j-miller/spaceships)
Wrote console-based Tic-Tac-Toe game in C++ utilizing the Minimax algorithm
Wrote multi-player chess game with GUI using Python
Designed and built a self-driving toy car, programmed in C++
Wrote object-detection and collision avoidance algorithms to allow the vehicle to autonomously navigate an obstacle course
Interfaced ultrasonic sensors, motor controllers, Hall effect transistors, and an accelerometer with an Arduino microcontroller using SPI and I^2^C protocols

points.header: Aerial Multispectral Imaging Engineering Capstone (September 2018 – April 2020)
points.blurb: Our capstone team sought to use autonomous drones mounted with multispectral cameras to survey vineyards and provide valuable information and guidance for fertilizer placement, water usage, and crop health. We also provided a custom-built UI for vineyard owners to manage and view their data.
items: Worked with a team of 8 in a 2-year long capstone project to design and build an autonomous aerial multispectral imaging platform
Designed and implemented web application for uploading raw data, viewing GPS-based map overlays of multispectral data, and analyzing crop health using multispectral imagery
Designed and implemented data processing system for stitching together thousands of images into a mosaic and elevation map for visualizing changes in crop health over time
Managed client uploads of multi-gigabyte raw data to AWS S3 for automated processing
Developed Python backend for processing and serving multispectral crop data
Designed, built, and programmed IoT pedometer which was able to track step counts with > 95% accuracy and transmit results wirelessly to a paired computer
Wrote pedometer-side code in C++ with a cross-platform Python GUI client
GitHub repo [here](https://github.com/isaac-j-miller/Pedometer)

points.header: Interlock for Interlock for Helium Nanodroplet Isolation Spectrometer (September 2018 – August 2019)
items: Independently designed, built, installed, and maintained a flexble, microcontroller-driven digital interlock system
Wrote device firmware in C++ to prevent or mitigate damage to delicate scientific instruments in the case of malfunction
Designed and implemented circuitry on a custom-made printed circuit board
Built a GUI using Python to modify Interlock configuration
Wrote a comprehensive user manual to explain device features and troubleshoot problems
Interfaced the microcontroller with a Raspberry Pi to connect to the internet and provide remote control over the lab

points.blurb: During my 3 years of work as a research assistant in the Raston Lab at JMU, I co-authored four peer-reviewed publications, contributed to three conference papers and presented our lab's findings at several national and international-level conferences.
items:
The Synchrotron-based Far-infrared Spectrum of Glycolaldehyde

Isaac Miller, Ty Faulkner, John Saunier, and Paul L. Raston

points.header: Best Senior Capstone Business Idea at the Madison Engineering xChange (Spring 2020)
points.blurb: This award is given to the senior capstone team voted to have the most entrepreneurial value
This award is given to one outstanding student in the area of physical chemistry each year
Developed innovative traffic solution using micro-controllers and IoT concepts

points.header: 1^st^ Place Junior Engineering Capstone at the Madison Engineering xChange (Spring 2019)
